study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if ursolic acid (UA) supplementation could enhance the anti-inflammatory effects of resistance training (RT) by reducing blood inflammatory markers in healthy men.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in serum cytokine concentrations (TNF-α, IL-10, IL-6) after 8 weeks of RT combined with UA supplementation compared to placebo. The results suggest UA did not potentiate anti-inflammatory effects in this context.
population_specificity: Healthy men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effect of resistance training, endurance training, and supplement intake on muscle cell bioenergetics.
results_summary: The study found that resistance training, endurance training, and supplements can enhance mitochondrial biogenesis, fat oxidation, myofibril synthesis, and increase VO.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of resistance training in improving testosterone levels in men with functional hypogonadism.
results_summary: The study suggests that resistance training, along with lifestyle modifications like dietary changes and improved sleep, can help normalize testosterone levels in men with functional hypogonadism. It highlights the importance of a multidisciplinary approach for treatment.
population_specificity: Adult men with functional hypogonadism (borderline low testosterone due to aging or comorbid conditions like diabetes, obesity, or metabolic syndrome).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of creatine supplementation immediately before versus immediately after unilateral resistance training on muscle hypertrophy and strength.
results_summary: The study found significant increases in muscle thickness and strength over time, with no differences between creatine ingestion strategies before or after training. Total training volume was similar between conditions.
population_specificity: Recreationally active young adults (7 males, 3 females; age 23±5 years).
effective_dosage: 0.1 g/kg of body mass of creatine monohydrate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a single CBD supplementation on performance and muscle damage after resistance training in well-trained participants.
results_summary: The study found a significant decrease in one-repetition maximum back squat performance after 24 hours, but no other results were provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Healthy, well-trained participants (16 out of 21 completed the study).
study_duration: Single dose intervention (follow-up measurements at 24 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of combined aerobic-resistance training (CARET) and broccoli supplementation on dectin-1 levels and insulin resistance in men with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D).
results_summary: The combination of CARET and broccoli supplementation significantly reduced plasma dectin-1 levels and improved insulin resistance and other complications of T2D compared to control groups. The TS and TP groups showed the most notable improvements.
population_specificity: Forty-four males with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether resistance training, combined with aerobic exercise and protein supplementation, could enhance myokine expression and exert tumor-suppressive effects in prostate cancer patients on androgen deprivation therapy.
results_summary: The intervention reduced body weight, fat mass, and percent body fat while increasing lean mass and strength. Postintervention serum showed increased oncostatin M (OSM) levels and reduced prostate cancer cell growth compared to baseline.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer patients (age 73.3 ± 5.6 yr) undergoing androgen deprivation therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (supervised resistance training, self-directed aerobic exercise, and protein supplementation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of moderate-to-high intensity resistance circuit training (MHRCT) combined with Ursolic acid (UA) supplementation on metabolic and inflammatory markers in young older obese women.
results_summary: The study found that MHRCT significantly reduced IL-15, IL-6, Insulin, and HOMA-IR levels, while increasing BDNF and Irisin levels. UA supplementation further enhanced these effects, particularly for BDNF and metabolic markers.
population_specificity: Young older obese women (ages 50-70, BMI ≥ 30 and <40 kg/m2).
effective_dosage: UA was ingested as a capsule three times per day (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of creatine supplementation timing (pre-, during-, or post-exercise) on muscle loading and performance gains in resistance training.
results_summary: Emerging evidence suggests greater benefits when creatine is consumed after exercise compared to pre-exercise, though methodological limitations and lack of mechanistic data prevent definitive conclusions. The study highlights the need for further research on physiological effects and optimal timing.
population_specificity: Athletes engaged in various sports (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D3 supplementation during elastic-band resistance training (EBT) reduces oxidative stress and improves antioxidant indices in healthy men.
results_summary: Elastic resistance training improved antioxidant defense, but vitamin D3 supplementation did not show a synergistic effect on reducing oxidative stress indices. Significant differences were observed in MDA, SOD, TAC, and GPX between the EBT-vitamin D3 group and the vitamin D3-only or control groups, but not between the EBT-vitamin D3 and EBT-placebo groups.
population_specificity: Forty healthy men with serum vitamin D levels between 20–25 ng/mL.
effective_dosage: 50,000 IU vitamin D3 or placebo once every 2 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the existing evidence on the effects of protein hydrolysate supplementation on fat-free mass and strength outcomes during resistance training.
results_summary: The study conducted a structured literature review but did not provide specific results in the abstract regarding the effects of protein hydrolysate on fat-free mass or strength.
population_specificity: Healthy participants over 18 years old undergoing resistance training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplements (leucine, whey, soy, creatine) enhance the effects of resistance training in improving muscle mass and function in pre-frail and frail elderly individuals.
results_summary: Resistance training alone increased muscle mass and function, but none of the tested supplements (leucine, whey, soy, creatine) provided additional benefits. No sex-based differences were observed in response to whey supplementation.
population_specificity: Pre-frail and frail elderly (154 women, 46 men; mean age 72 ± 6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic Capsiate supplementation combined with resistance training improves muscular adaptations, inflammatory response, and performance in untrained men.
results_summary: Chronic Capsiate supplementation increased fat-free mass and upper body strength but had no effect on lower body strength or inflammatory response. The majority of the fat-free mass increase was due to increased total body water.
population_specificity: Untrained young men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of creatine supplementation combined with resistance training on lean tissue mass and strength in aging adults, comparing different dosing strategies and timing of ingestion.
results_summary: Creatine supplementation, regardless of dosing strategy, enhanced lean tissue mass and strength gains from resistance training compared to placebo. Higher-dose creatine (>5 g/day) improved leg press strength, while lower-dose creatine (≤5 g/day) with a loading phase increased chest press strength. Supplementing only on training days also boosted lean tissue mass and strength.
population_specificity: Aging adults
effective_dosage: Lower dose: ≤5 g/day; higher dose: >5 g/day; loading phase: ≥20 g/day for 5-7 days

study_goal: To examine the efficacy of creatine supplementation and potential sex differences during supervised whole-body resistance training on bone and muscle properties in older adults.
results_summary: Creatine supplementation combined with resistance training increased or maintained bone area in the tibia and improved lower leg muscle density, with some sex-specific effects observed. No significant changes were noted in the radius or forearm muscle.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 58 ± 6 years; 39 men, 31 women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare various methods of adjusting resistance training intensity and their implications for athlete performance and development.
results_summary: The study found that different intensity adjustment methods (e.g., linear loading, 1RM, RPE, VBT) have distinct advantages and limitations, with subjective and objective methods addressing daily performance variability. Future monitoring may benefit from combining outcome and process measures to guide training adaptations.
population_specificity: Athletes, particularly novices and those returning from injury or training load reductions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Vitamin D supplementation enhances the efficacy of resistance training in increasing muscle strength and lean body mass in Vitamin D-deficient young men.
results_summary: The study found that Vitamin D supplementation did not enhance resistance training-induced increases in muscle strength or lean body mass in Vitamin D-deficient young men, despite significantly raising serum Vitamin D levels. Energy and nutrient intake (except Vitamin D) and training loads were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Vitamin D-deficient young men (baseline serum 25(OH)D < 50 nmol/L).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of creatine supplementation for improving strength and exercise performance in females, particularly pre- and post-menopausal women.
results_summary: Creatine supplementation was found effective for improving strength and exercise performance in pre-menopausal females, while post-menopausal females may benefit from high doses (0.3 g·kg) in skeletal muscle size and function. Hormone-related changes suggest supplementation may be particularly important during menses, pregnancy, post-partum, and menopause.
population_specificity: Females, specifically pre-menopausal and post-menopausal women.
effective_dosage: High doses (0.3 g·kg) for post-menopausal females; specific dosage for pre-menopausal females not mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of creatine supplementation, with and without resistance training, on muscle and bone properties in older adults and justify future research in populations with sarcopenia-related conditions.
results_summary: The study found that creatine supplementation, especially when combined with resistance training, has favorable effects on muscle, bone, and fat mass, as well as strength and physical performance in healthy older adults, but research is limited in populations with sarcopenia or related conditions.
population_specificity: Older adults, particularly those with sarcopenia, osteoporosis, osteosarcopenia, sarcopenic obesity, physical frailty, or cachexia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of hydrogen-rich water (HRW) supplementation on physiological, perceptual, and performance responses during and after resistance training.
results_summary: HRW improved muscle function by speeding up lunge performance, reduced lactate levels during and after exercise, and alleviated delayed onset of muscle soreness compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 12 men aged 23.8 ± 1.9 years.
study_duration: Acute (single session with follow-up measurements up to 24 hours post-exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether creatine supplementation alone (independent of exercise) could improve muscle mass, bone strength, and brain function in older adults.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that creatine may have favorable effects on muscle, bone, and brain health in older adults, though adherence to resistance training guidelines remains low. The review examines existing research but does not provide specific outcome data.
population_specificity: Older adults (> 55 years of age)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of fat-free mass (FFM) on resting metabolic rate (RMR), appetite, and energy intake (EI) in older adults.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding resistance training's effects, only mentioning the investigation of FFM's relationship with RMR, appetite, and EI.
population_specificity: 39 healthy older adults (age: 66 ± 4 years, BMI: 25.1 ± 3.5 kg∙m²).

study_goal: To determine if whey protein plus vitamin D supplementation combined with progressive resistance training (PRT) improves glycaemic control, body composition, muscle function, and cardiometabolic risk factors in middle-aged and older adults with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that whey protein plus vitamin D supplementation did not enhance the effects of PRT on glycaemic control, body composition, muscle strength, or cardiometabolic risk factors, except for minor improvements in IL-10, TNF-α, and sit-to-stand performance.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese adults aged 50-75 years with type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: 20g whey protein each morning plus 20g post-exercise, combined with vitamin D.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of marine phytoplankton supplementation on perceived recovery and ground reaction forces in humans after resistance training, as well as its impact on muscle cell recovery markers in rats.
results_summary: Marine phytoplankton improved perceived recovery in humans post-training and restored force development to baseline levels after overreaching, unlike placebo. In rats, the supplement was tested alongside exercise, but full results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Humans undergoing resistance training and rats in a muscle recovery model.
effective_dosage: 2.55 mg·d (rat model; human dosage not specified).
study_duration: 5 weeks (human trial); rat duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent evidence on the effectiveness of resistance training and other interventions for treating sarcopenic obesity in adult and older individuals.
results_summary: Resistance training was effective in improving lean mass or sarcopenia-related indices and reducing total adiposity, with beneficial effects on body composition. However, effects on muscle strength and functional ability were inconsistent.
population_specificity: Adult and older individuals, particularly those with sarcopenic obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether resistance training combined with peanut protein powder supplementation enhances strength and muscle mass in older individuals.
results_summary: The study examined the effects of resistance training with or without peanut protein supplementation on myofibrillar protein synthesis rates in older adults, but specific results regarding outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Older, untrained individuals (17 female, 22 male; age 58.6 ± 8.0 years; BMI 28.7 ± 5.8).
effective_dosage: 75 g powder daily (providing 30 g protein, >9.2 g essential amino acids, ~315 kcal).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 supplementation enhances resistance exercise-induced improvements in muscle inflammation, catabolism, and anabolism in older adults.
results_summary: Resistance training improved leg press strength and reduced inflammatory and catabolic markers, but omega-3 only enhanced isometric strength gains without affecting muscle volume, inflammation, or catabolism. Muscle quality improvements were attributed to resistance training, not omega-3.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 65-84 years (8 females).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining BCAA supplementation with resistance training enhances muscle mass, strength, and regulatory factors in postmenopausal women compared to resistance training alone.
results_summary: Resistance training significantly increased muscle mass, strength, and IGF-1 while decreasing myostatin in postmenopausal women, but BCAA supplementation did not further enhance these effects. Follistatin increased only in the BCAA group, but no differences were found between RT conditions over time.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (n=30)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute effects of a preworkout multi-ingredient admixture (PREW) versus carbohydrate (CHO) on resistance training volume and endurance substrate oxidation over a week-long microcycle.
results_summary: The study found higher resistance training volume (both per session and weekly) with PREW compared to CHO, along with measurements of fatty acid oxidation during endurance sessions and postworkout muscle function assessments.
population_specificity: Fourteen recreationally trained, middle-aged adults (seven females, 48.8 ± 4.7 years old).
effective_dosage: PREW or CHO ingested 15 minutes prior to each workout.
study_duration: Two identical microcycles (each comprising three resistance training workouts and two endurance sessions), separated by a two-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of vitamin D supplementation on responses to resistance training, particularly in older adults and individuals with chronic diseases like COPD.
results_summary: Resistance training over 13 weeks increased muscle strength (13%), muscle mass (9%), and endurance performance (23% for one-legged, 8% for whole-body), while also reducing visceral fat (-6%) and LDL levels. The abstract does not provide conclusive results on the impact of vitamin D supplementation.
population_specificity: 95 male and female participants (68 ± 5 years), including healthy individuals (n=71) and those with COPD (n=24).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of 24-g doses of rice and whey protein on body composition and performance outcomes following an 8-week resistance training program in resistance-trained males.
results_summary: Both rice and whey protein supplementation led to similar improvements in body composition (lean mass, fat-free mass) and performance (bench press and leg press strength) after 8 weeks of resistance training, with no significant differences between the two protein sources.
population_specificity: Healthy resistance-trained males (n=24, age 32.8±6.7 years).
effective_dosage: 24-g doses daily (isonitrogenous rice or whey protein concentrate).

study_goal: To assess the effects of 12 months of creatine supplementation and supervised, whole-body resistance training on bone mineral density, bone geometric properties, muscle accretion, and strength in older males.
results_summary: After 12 months, both creatine and placebo groups showed similar changes in bone mineral density, geometry, muscle mass, and strength, with no significant advantage from creatine supplementation. A trend (not statistically significant) was noted for some outcomes.
population_specificity: Older males

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness of blood flow restriction (BFR) training as a supplement to traditional resistance training in improving strength, muscle size, and sports performance in healthy athletes.
results_summary: The study found that BFR training significantly increased strength in 78% of studies, muscle size in 50%, and sports performance markers in 75% of cases compared to controls. The optimal occlusive cuff pressure varied widely (110-240 mm Hg), suggesting further research is needed.
population_specificity: Healthy athletes
effective_dosage: Occlusive cuff pressure ranged from 110 to 240 mm Hg (specific frequency not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of probiotic (Bacillus subtilis) supplementation on physical performance and body composition during offseason resistance training in female Division I athletes.
results_summary: Probiotic supplementation did not improve physical performance but led to greater reductions in body fat percentage compared to placebo. No other significant group differences were observed in strength or performance metrics.
population_specificity: Female Division I soccer and volleyball players (n=23, aged 19.6 ± 1.0 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of self-selected exercise intensities combined with whey protein or placebo supplementation on various health metrics in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that 12 weeks of self-selected resistance exercise and walking improved resting heart rate, body composition, muscle strength, and mobility in older adults, regardless of protein supplementation.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 55+ (34 males, 67 females).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of creatine supplementation during resistance training on skeletal muscle mass and exercise performance in physically active young adults.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study design suggests an investigation into creatine's impact on muscle mass and performance during resistance training.
population_specificity: Physically active young adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of resistance training (RT) combined with protein supplementation (PS) compared to RT alone or with a placebo in improving muscle strength and physical performance in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no statistical differences in upper-limb strength between RT combined with PS and RT alone or with a placebo. Secondary outcomes related to physical performance (SPPB, gait speed, 5CRT) were not fully detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly individuals (>60 years)

study_goal: To determine the effects of low (20 g) versus high (40 g) protein doses ingested post-exercise during resistance training in elderly males.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the outcomes of the protein supplementation intervention.
population_specificity: Elderly males (70.5±5.1 years) with novice resistance training experience.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and health effects of creatine monohydrate supplementation on resistance training practitioners by assessing blood and urine health indicators.
results_summary: Creatine monohydrate supplementation increased performance and body weight without adverse effects or changes in blood/urine markers, hepatic/renal function, or other physiological systems. The study concluded that creatine supplementation is safe for health in this context.
population_specificity: 18 males performing resistance training three times per week.
study_duration: 7 days of supplementation, with follow-up at 30 days post-supplementation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of resistance training, alone or combined with nutritional supplementation, in improving muscle strength and physical function in dynapenic older adults with low protein intake.
results_summary: Resistance training significantly improved handgrip strength, gait speed, and sit-to-stand performance, with large effect sizes. Combining resistance training with supplementation showed no additional benefits over resistance training alone.
population_specificity: Dynapenic older adults with low protein intake (n=69).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of strength training combined with vitamin C and E supplementation on perceived and performance fatigability in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results regarding the effects of resistance training.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors (BCS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effects of resistance training with and without protein supplementation on lean body mass and muscle strength among adult survivors of childhood cancer.
results_summary: The study found that supervised resistance training with protein supplementation was feasible but not more effective at increasing lean body mass or muscle strength than resistance training alone. Both groups showed increases in lean mass and strength over time, but there were no significant differences between the groups.
population_specificity: Adult survivors of childhood cancer aged 18 to <45 years.
effective_dosage: 21 g whey protein per day (90 kcal) for the supplementation group; placebo (sucrose, 90 kcal) for the control group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of acute almond supplementation on non-esterified fatty acid (NEFA) levels and exercise performance during cycling resistance training.
results_summary: The study found a slight increase in NEFA values (average 0.09 mg·dL) with almond supplementation, but no significant changes in maximum oxygen uptake or other performance and physiological parameters.
population_specificity: Five physically active male subjects (age 32.9 ± 12.7 years, height 178.5 ± 3.3 cm, weight 81.3 ± 9.7 kg).
study_duration: Two cycling resistance training sessions separated by 7-10 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of six months of resistance training, with or without protein and vitamin supplementation, on chromosomal integrity in institutionalized elderly individuals.
results_summary: Resistance training improved fitness (6-minute walking and chair rise performance) but did not affect chromosomal integrity (no changes in genotoxicity or cytotoxicity parameters). Micronuclei frequency correlated significantly with age.
population_specificity: Institutionalized elderly women and men (65-98 years).
effective_dosage: Twice per week resistance training (supplement details not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a multi-ingredient supplement versus a carbohydrate-only supplement on recovery of muscle function and perceived soreness after hard resistance training sessions.
results_summary: The multi-ingredient supplement hastened recovery of muscular contractile properties and performance compared to carbohydrates alone, though both conditions similarly increased delayed onset muscle soreness (DOMS). Vertical jump performance decreased with carbohydrates but not with the multi-ingredient supplement, and upper-body strength/power recovered faster with the multi-ingredient supplement.
population_specificity: 10 resistance-trained men (26.9 ± 7.4 years)
study_duration: 5-day intervention periods (with assessments at 1, 24, and 48 hours post-workout)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of resistance exercise and dietary supplementation with cholecalciferol on nutritional status indicators in adults with stage 4 chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found that supplementation with cholecalciferol improved serum concentrations of 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) and, when combined with resistance exercise, improved muscle function as measured by handgrip strength in patients with CKD not on dialysis.
population_specificity: Adults with stage 4 CKD (estimated glomerular filtration rate between 15 and 29 mL/min/1.73 m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether creatine supplementation combined with resistance training improves body composition, muscle strength, and physical function in prostate cancer patients undergoing androgen deprivation therapy.
results_summary: The study is designed to assess the effects of creatine supplementation alongside resistance training, but results are not yet reported in the abstract. The primary and secondary endpoints will be evaluated post-intervention.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer patients receiving androgen deprivation therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Ursolic Acid (UA) supplementation enhances the effects of High-Intensity Resistance Training (HIRT) on serum levels of irisin, CRP, IL-6, and TNF-α in low-activity men.
results_summary: UA supplementation significantly increased irisin levels and reduced CRP, IL-6, and TNF-α levels in the HIRT+UA group compared to the HIRT+placebo group, suggesting UA may enhance HIRT's benefits.
population_specificity: Healthy, low-activity men.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of antioxidant supplements on exercise, focusing on oxidative stress, recovery, performance, and cellular adaptation.
results_summary: Antioxidant supplementation does not block adaptive cellular responses to exhaustive exercise but may impair muscle hypertrophy signaling. Chronic antioxidant use may hinder exercise adaptations, while acute use can delay fatigue and reduce recovery time.
population_specificity: Athletes and individuals engaging in resistance training (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether whey protein supplementation before or after resistance training affects oxidative stress and antioxidant enzyme activity in pre-conditioned older women.
results_summary: All groups showed improvements in oxidative stress markers and antioxidant enzyme activity, with whey protein supplementation significantly reducing plasma uric acid levels compared to placebo, though no differences were observed based on timing of protein intake.
population_specificity: Older women (≥60 years) who were already pre-conditioned.
effective_dosage: 35 g of whey protein or placebo pre- and post-training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of resistance training and other exercise interventions in countering sarcopenia in older adults to inform clinical guidelines.
results_summary: The study found high-quality evidence supporting resistance training's positive effects on muscle mass, strength, and physical performance in older adults. High-intensity resistance training (80% 1RM) was recommended for maximal strength gains, though low-intensity training also showed benefits.
population_specificity: Older adults, particularly those with or at risk of sarcopenia.
effective_dosage: High-intensity resistance training (80% 1RM) recommended; low-intensity (≤50% 1RM) also effective.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining protein supplementation with resistance training (RT) enhances muscle mass, strength, and function in the elderly more effectively than RT alone.
results_summary: The study found that combining protein supplementation with RT significantly improved muscle mass (FFM and ASMM) and strength (handgrip, knee extension, leg press) in older adults, but no significant effects were observed on muscle function.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (age not specified, but implied by context of age-related muscle loss).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of whey protein supplementation combined with resistance training on body mass and muscular strength in different populations.
results_summary: The study found that whey protein supplementation with resistance training improved lean mass, reduced fat mass, and increased muscular strength in healthy and younger individuals (<40 years), but not in those with pathological conditions. Age and training duration influenced the outcomes, with younger age and longer training duration associated with greater improvements.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals and those with pathological conditions; subgroup analysis focused on younger individuals (<40 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of whey protein supplementation combined with resistance training on body composition, muscular strength, functional capacity, and plasma-metabolism biomarkers in older women with sarcopenic obesity.
results_summary: The whey protein group showed greater increases in appendicular lean soft tissue and greater decreases in total and trunk fat mass compared to the placebo group. Both groups improved in muscular strength, waist-hip ratio, functional capacity, and other plasma-metabolism biomarkers, but no significant differences were found between conditions for these outcomes.
population_specificity: Older women with sarcopenic obesity (appendicular lean soft tissue < 15.02 kg and body fat mass ≥ 35%).
effective_dosage: 35 g of whey protein daily, combined with supervised resistance training (8 exercises, 3 × 8-12 reps, 3 times a week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of whey protein supplementation combined with resistance training on cellular health in pre-conditioned older women.
results_summary: The study found that whey protein supplementation (pre- or post-training) combined with resistance training increased intracellular water and lean soft tissue while reducing the extracellular/intracellular water ratio. Resistance training alone improved phase angle, regardless of supplementation.
population_specificity: Pre-conditioned older women (n=70, aged not specified)
effective_dosage: 35 g of whey protein or placebo pre- and post-training, 3 times per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how resistance training affects antioxidant status and the impact of combining antioxidant supplementation with resistance training on muscle adaptations.
results_summary: The study suggests that resistance training can modulate antioxidant status and that reactive oxygen species play a role in cellular adaptation, though excessive amounts may cause muscle damage and impair recovery. Antioxidant supplementation may help mitigate these effects but could interfere with redox signaling benefits.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion, no specific population mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of resistance training and nutrition in reducing chronic pain by improving mitochondrial capacity and lowering inflammatory signaling.
results_summary: The study suggests that resistance training, combined with proper nutrition, can reduce chronic pain sensitivity by enhancing mitochondrial function and decreasing inflammatory signals to C-fibers. Nutritional interventions were also found to indirectly inhibit prostaglandin E2 and improve antioxidant defenses in skeletal muscle.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic pain related to inflammatory disorders or nutrient deficiencies (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether multi-ingredient protein (MIP) supplements enhance resistance training-induced gains in muscle mass and strength compared to protein-only or placebo supplementation.
results_summary: MIP supplements combined with resistance training led to greater gains in fat-free mass and strength compared to non-MIP supplements, particularly in untrained and older individuals. However, MIP supplements were not superior to protein-only supplements when directly compared.
population_specificity: Healthy adults, with subgroup analyses focusing on untrained and older participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of omega-3 PUFAs in the prevention and treatment of sarcopenia, including their potential synergistic effects with resistance training and protein supplementation.
results_summary: The study found growing evidence for the beneficial effects of omega-3 PUFAs in sarcopenic older persons, potentially enhancing the effects of exercise and protein supplementation, though optimal dosage and usage require further research.
population_specificity: Sarcopenic older persons (geriatric population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential therapeutic role of creatine supplementation in augmenting exercise adaptations, particularly for individuals with cancer at risk for muscle loss.
results_summary: The abstract summarizes evidence supporting creatine's benefits on lean body mass, strength, and physical function in various clinical populations, suggesting its therapeutic potential in exercise oncology. Mechanisms of action and physiological roles of creatine are also discussed.
population_specificity: Individuals with cancer at heightened risk for muscle loss, as well as various aging/clinical populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if creatine supplementation combined with exercise provides additive benefits for skeletal muscle, bone, and mental health in healthy older adults compared to exercise alone.
results_summary: The study found that continuous low-dose creatine supplementation combined with at least 12 weeks of resistance training may improve strength, functional capacity, and lean mass in older adults, with more consistent benefits in women. Potential bone mineral density increases may require at least 1 year of supplementation and resistance training, while no additive effects were observed for mental health.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults, with noted gender differences in response.
effective_dosage: Continuous and daily low-dose creatine (specific amount not stated).
study_duration: At least 12 weeks for muscle-related benefits, at least 1 year for potential bone benefits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a 10-week instructor-led resistance training program on functional strength and body composition in older adults with pre-sarcopenia.
results_summary: The intervention showed no significant effect on the primary outcome (SPPB) in the total cohort but improved functional strength in the male subcohort and significantly enhanced body composition (increased lean mass, reduced fat mass) in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Men and women aged 70 years with pre-sarcopenia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (resistance training regimen details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 12 weeks of resistance training combined with protein supplementation on body composition, muscle atrophy/hypertrophy markers, and heat shock response in healthy older adults.
results_summary: Resistance training improved lean body mass and physical test results in both exercise groups, with additional benefits in fat reduction and muscle signaling changes (favoring protein synthesis and heat shock response) observed in the exercise plus protein group. Protein supplementation alone had no significant effect on muscle markers.
population_specificity: 38 healthy sedentary older adults (63.5 ± 4.4 years, 18 male/20 female).
effective_dosage: 45-minute supervised resistance training sessions, 3 times per week (using bodyweight and elastic bands); protein supplementation details not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether resistance training combined with dietary protein supplementation could effectively maintain body composition and physical fitness after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in lean body mass loss between groups, but resistance training with protein supplementation led to a greater increase in relative lower-limb muscle strength compared to controls or protein supplementation alone.
population_specificity: Seventy-six women with obesity undergoing Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified (additional whey protein intake and supervised strength training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of pre- vs. post-workout nutrition on strength, body composition, and metabolism in trained females undergoing high-intensity resistance training.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in body composition or leg press strength between groups, but pre- and post-workout supplementation led to greater increases in bench press strength compared to the control. Pre-workout supplementation also enhanced fat oxidation immediately post-exercise.
population_specificity: Trained females (mean age 20.5±2.2 years, height 165.2±5.7 cm, body mass 66.5±11.4 kg).
effective_dosage: 16g CHO/25g PRO supplement consumed either pre- or post-training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether whey protein supplementation before or after resistance training improves metabolic and inflammatory profiles in older women.
results_summary: Whey protein supplementation, whether taken before or after resistance training, led to greater improvements in appendicular lean soft tissue and cholesterol ratios compared to placebo. Post-resistance training whey protein also showed additional benefits in reducing body fat and improving metabolic health.
population_specificity: Pre-conditioned older women (n=70)
effective_dosage: 35 g of whey protein or placebo pre- and post-resistance training

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of resistance training and epicatechin supplementation on muscle strength, follistatin, and myostatin levels in older adults with sarcopenia.
results_summary: The combination of resistance training and epicatechin (RT+EP) showed the greatest increase in follistatin, follistatin/myostatin ratio, leg press, and chest press compared to resistance training alone, epicatechin alone, or placebo. Myostatin decreased significantly only in RT+EP and RT groups, while appendicular muscle mass index and timed up and go test improved in all experimental groups compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 62 males with sarcopenia, aged 68.63 ± 2.86 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between whey protein supplementation, body composition, and muscle strength in resistance-trained individuals.
results_summary: Whey protein supplementation was inversely correlated with whole-body, trunk, and android fat mass, but no correlations were found between muscle strength outcomes and whey protein supplementation.
population_specificity: 49 healthy males aged 18-35 years with at least 1 year of resistance training experience.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the time course of strength increase with creatine supplementation during resistance training and whether it prevents muscle damage.
results_summary: Creatine supplementation significantly increased strength within two weeks for some exercises and maintained this effect through eight weeks, but it did not prevent muscle damage—markers of muscle damage were higher in the creatine group.
population_specificity: Young males

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a higher-intensity, progressive, multi-component intervention (including resistance training) improves physical function more than usual care physical therapy in older adults recovering from acute hospitalization.
results_summary: The study is a randomized controlled trial, so results are not yet available, but the intervention includes lower extremity resistance training at 80% of 1-repetition maximum, task-specific activities, gait/balance training, and nutritional supplementation. Outcomes will be measured at multiple time points up to 180 days.
population_specificity: Older adults with deconditioning following acute hospitalization, referred for home health physical therapy (n=200).
effective_dosage: Lower extremity resistance training at 80% of 1-repetition maximum (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming protein supplements with meals versus between meals affects resistance training-induced changes in body composition in adults.
results_summary: Consuming protein supplements with meals, compared to between meals, was associated with better weight control (56% vs. 72% increase in body mass), similar improvements in lean mass (94% vs. 90%), greater reductions in fat mass (87% vs. 59%), and higher increases in lean-to-fat mass ratio (100% vs. 84%).
population_specificity: Adults engaging in resistance training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acute effects of sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) supplementation on explosive power mechanisms (Study 1) and whether chronic supplementation enhances neuromuscular adaptations during a 10-week resistance training program (Study 2).
results_summary: Study 1 found that NaHCO3 reduced the decline in maximal rate of torque development (RTDMAX) by ~20% compared to placebo after a leg extension task, though both conditions showed declines in maximal torque (MVT) and RTD. Study 2 found no additional benefits from chronic NaHCO3 supplementation on explosive power adaptations over 10 weeks of resistance training.
population_specificity: Eight resistance-trained participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of resistance training versus endurance training on basal metabolic rate, cardiovascular fitness, and serum leptin levels in obese adolescent boys.
results_summary: Resistance training decreased leptin levels and increased VO2max, indicating improved cardiovascular fitness and hormonal control of fat metabolism, though basal metabolic rate only increased significantly in the endurance training group.
population_specificity: Obese adolescent boys (age 16.81 ± 0.91 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of whey protein supplementation, with or without energy restriction and resistance training, on body composition changes in women.
results_summary: Whey protein supplementation modestly increased lean mass but did not affect fat mass. The beneficial effect on lean mass was lost when combined with resistance training but was more robust when combined with energy restriction.
population_specificity: Women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined aerobic exercise and progressive resistance training (RT) improves cognition more than a balance and toning control intervention in older adults with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI), and whether adding cognitive training and vitamin D enhances efficacy.
results_summary: The study hypothesizes that combined aerobic and resistance training will outperform balance and toning in improving cognition in MCI patients, with potential synergistic benefits from cognitive training and vitamin D. Results are pending as the trial is ongoing.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 60-85 with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI).
effective_dosage: Not specified for resistance training; vitamin D supplementation at 3 × 10,000 IU/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if 12 weeks of resistance training could improve body composition and metabolic syndrome (MetS) in prostate cancer patients on androgen deprivation therapy (ADT), and whether protein supplementation enhanced these effects.
results_summary: Resistance training significantly improved lean mass, reduced sarcopenia prevalence, decreased body fat percentage, increased strength, and enhanced quality of life, but did not significantly alter MetS or physical function. Protein supplementation did not provide additional benefits.
population_specificity: Hypogonadal prostate cancer patients on ADT.
effective_dosage: Resistance training 3 days per week; protein supplementation (50 g/day) for TRAINPRO and PRO groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the physiologic effects of spaceflight and test countermeasures, including resistance training, in a ground-based model using a 70-day head-down tilt bed rest study.
results_summary: The abstract does not present specific outcomes related to resistance training but describes the standardized conditions and integration of studies, including individualized resistance training as part of the countermeasures.
population_specificity: Bed rest subjects undergoing rigorous medical and psychological screening, simulating spaceflight conditions.
effective_dosage: Individualized resistance training 6 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a multi-ingredient dietary preworkout supplement on vascular function at rest and after acute resistance exercise in young, recreationally active adults.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the supplement on vascular function.
population_specificity: Young, recreationally active adults (12 participants: 9 males, 3 females; mean age 24.5 ± 3.4 years; BMI 24.3 ± 4.7 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of resistance training and nutritional supplementation on muscle mass and muscle quality in very old institutionalized adults with impaired health status.
results_summary: Resistance training significantly improved muscle quality of the lower extremities after 6 months, but did not change skeletal muscle mass. Nutritional supplementation did not enhance the training effect. Participants with lower baseline muscle quality benefited the most.
population_specificity: 54 very old institutionalized adults (82.4±6.0 years) with impaired health status.
effective_dosage: Not specified (elastic band resistance training and nutritional supplementation details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a protein supplement enhances muscular strength and body composition during a concurrent strength and endurance training program in sedentary young adults.
results_summary: Protein supplementation led to greater strength gains in males (bench press and hip sled) and greater fat mass reduction in females, while lean mass changes were similar between groups. Males in the protein group also showed increased lean mass at 3 months, but not at 6 months.
population_specificity: Sedentary males (n=26) and females (n=25), aged 18-25.
effective_dosage: 42 g protein (PRO) or carbohydrate (CON) supplement twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether whey protein supplementation enhances the recovery of contractile function following resistance training in young, healthy adults.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found small to medium positive effects of whey protein on restoring contractile function within 24 to 96 hours post-exercise, though results were inconsistent across individual studies. The overall evidence supports its efficacy but highlights the need for further research.
population_specificity: Young, healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of whey protein supplementation (WPS) on rehabilitation outcomes in a frail, hospitalized elderly population.
results_summary: WPS significantly increased protein intake and improved grip strength and knee extensor force compared to the control group. A positive correlation was found between changes in prealbumin and knee extensor force improvement.
population_specificity: Frail, hospitalized elderly men and women (n=47).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of whey protein supplementation on muscular strength, hypertrophy, and muscular quality in older women preconditioned to resistance training.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study design suggests an investigation into the benefits of whey protein combined with resistance training for older women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 10 weeks of combined aerobic and resistance training, with or without isoflavone supplementation, improved climacteric symptoms in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Combined training significantly reduced climacteric symptoms in both groups (45-50% reduction in symptoms), but isoflavone supplementation did not provide additional benefits. The absence of symptoms increased notably in both groups.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (aged 54.4 ± 5.4 years, BMI 26.6 ± 3.0 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: Not specified for resistance training; isoflavone dosage not detailed in abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of whey protein supplementation consumed either immediately before or after resistance training on skeletal muscle mass, muscular strength, and functional capacity in pre-conditioned older women.
results_summary: The study found that resistance training combined with whey protein supplementation (either pre- or post-exercise) improved skeletal muscle mass, muscular strength, and functional capacity in older women, though the abstract does not specify the magnitude or statistical significance of these effects.
population_specificity: Pre-conditioned older women (70 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether creatine supplementation combined with resistance training leads to region-specific muscle hypertrophy, particularly comparing upper limbs, lower limbs, and trunk in resistance-trained young adult men.
results_summary: Both creatine and placebo groups showed significant improvements in lean soft tissue, but the creatine group achieved greater increases, with upper limb improvements (7.1%) notably higher than lower limb (3.2%) and trunk (2.1%). The placebo group showed no significant differences in segmental muscle hypertrophy.
population_specificity: Resistance-trained young adult men (mean age 22.7 ± 3.0 years, mean BMI 23.0 ± 2.5 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of different exercise modalities, including resistance training, on body composition, muscle strength, and physical function in older adults with sarcopenic obesity.
results_summary: Resistance training showed increases in muscle strength, though results on muscle mass were contradictory. Improvements in physical function were noted when resistance training was combined with aerobic training and nutritional supplementation.
population_specificity: Healthy community-dwelling adults aged ≥60 years with sarcopenic obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of inflammation and autoimmunity, particularly related to HSP70, in the pathogenesis of salt-sensitive hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that immune reactivity to HSP70 contributes to salt-induced hypertension by impairing kidney function and disrupting the pressure natriuresis relationship. Regulatory T cells were shown to ameliorate hypertension, suggesting an autoimmune component in essential hypertension.
population_specificity: Adults with essential hypertension (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the diagnosis and management of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), particularly focusing on the salt-wasting phenotype and its implications.
results_summary: The study highlights that salt-wasting CAH can lead to life-threatening complications if undiagnosed, emphasizing the importance of newborn screening. It also discusses challenges in diagnosis and management, including the need for supraphysiologic glucocorticoid doses.
population_specificity: Children with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), particularly those with 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether topical CFTR gene replacement therapy to the lungs improves clinical outcomes in people with cystic fibrosis and to assess any adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in respiratory function in most trials, though one study reported temporary improvement. Some participants experienced "influenza-like" symptoms, and there was evidence of increased salt transport in lower airway cells, but these outcomes lacked direct clinical relevance.
population_specificity: People with confirmed cystic fibrosis (155 participants across three trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the physiological role of guanylate cyclase C (GC-C) in intestinal salt and water homeostasis and its implications for intestinal disorders.
results_summary: The study found that GC-C regulates electrolyte and fluid balance in the intestine, influences intestinal microflora composition, and modulates inflammation and injury. Therapeutic GC-C ligands effectively treat constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome and reduce abdominal pain.
population_specificity: Neonatal intestine (familial GC-C mutations), murine models, and human studies on irritable bowel syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if telmisartan, an ARB, effectively lowers systolic blood pressure in hemodialysis patients when added to standard antihypertensive therapy, considering factors like salt load and volume status.
results_summary: The study found no significant average effect of telmisartan compared to placebo on systolic blood pressure in hemodialysis patients, with high inter-individual variability in responses. The results suggest challenges in standardizing antihypertensive drug efficacy in this population due to confounding factors like salt load and volume status.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients with hypertension

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an improved salt-restriction spoon and health education in reducing salt intake and improving salt-restriction attitudes among home cooks.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly higher usage and correct usage rates of the salt-restriction spoon, reduced daily salt intake by 1.42 g, and decreased 24-hour urinary sodium excretion by 34.84 mmol, with significant improvements in perceived barriers and cues to action compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 403 adult residents in two Beijing villages responsible for home cooking.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved use of an improved salt-restriction spoon).

study_goal: The researchers reviewed the development of radiotracers for ionotropic and metabotropic glutamate receptors, focusing on their use in PET imaging for clinical or preclinical purposes.
results_summary: The study found that early radiotracer development for ionotropic receptors was unsuccessful, while recent efforts for metabotropic receptors (mGluR1, mGluR2, mGluR5) showed promise, with some radiopharmaceuticals being evaluated or used in clinical trials. Radiosynthesis methods included traditional carbon-11 and fluorine-18 labeling, as well as newer techniques like iodionium salt for fluorine-18 labeling.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on radiotracer development and evaluation, not human subjects).

study_goal: To evaluate the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of colistimethate sodium dry powder for inhalation (DPI) and tobramycin DPI for treating Pseudomonas aeruginosa lung infection in cystic fibrosis (CF).
results_summary: Both colistimethate sodium DPI and tobramycin DPI were non-inferior to nebulised tobramycin in improving FEV1%, but long-term efficacy and cost-effectiveness remain uncertain. The economic analysis suggested colistimethate sodium DPI may produce fewer QALYs than nebulised tobramycin, and tobramycin DPI was unlikely to be cost-effective at its current price.
population_specificity: Individuals with cystic fibrosis and chronic Pseudomonas aeruginosa lung infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess sodium intake levels and salt reduction measures in six Southeast Asian countries.
results_summary: The study found that sodium intake in most Southeast Asian countries exceeded WHO recommendations, primarily from added salt and sauces, and highlighted insufficient evidence on salt intake assessment methods.
population_specificity: Six Southeast Asian countries (Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the challenges faced by patients with diabetes and/or heart disease when modifying their diet, including salt intake, in response to clinical recommendations.
results_summary: The study identified common challenges in diet modification, such as self-discipline, knowledge, and managing the social significance of food, but did not specifically evaluate the effects of salt reduction. Vulnerable groups faced additional barriers like affordability and language comprehension.
population_specificity: Adult patients with diabetes and/or heart disease in North America, Europe, and Australia/New Zealand.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the molecular mechanisms of Na/K-ATPase signaling in regulating sodium reabsorption and its protective role against sodium retention-related volume expansion and blood pressure increase.
results_summary: The study found that activation of Na/K-ATPase signaling in renal proximal tubules promotes sodium excretion, counteracting volume expansion and blood pressure elevation, suggesting a protective rather than harmful role in hypertension.
population_specificity: Not specified (mechanistic study, likely animal or cellular models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify genetic mechanisms underlying diastolic dysfunction in heart failure using a rodent model (Dahl salt-sensitive rats) and explore how specific quantitative trait loci (QTLs) influence both blood pressure and diastolic function.
results_summary: The study found that distinct QTLs can temporarily or permanently improve diastolic dysfunction in DSS rats, with long-term protection requiring specific combinations of QTLs. It also revealed that blood pressure reduction alone does not restore diastolic function, but rather specific genes integrated into both blood pressure and diastolic function pathways are responsible.
population_specificity: Dahl salt-sensitive (DSS) rats, a rodent model of diastolic heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fluid and salt restriction would decrease postoperative complications compared with a liberal fluid regimen in patients undergoing major gastrointestinal resectional surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in major complication rates, length of hospital stay, or in-hospital deaths between the restricted and liberal fluid and salt regimens. Substantial differences in weight change, serum sodium, osmolality, and urine:serum osmolality ratio were observed between the groups.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing major gastrointestinal resectional surgery (194 colorectal resections and 46 oesophagogastric resections).
effective_dosage: Restricted group received median sodium input of 142 (93-218) mmol during surgery; control group received 282 (213-339) mmol.
study_duration: Duration of hospital stay (median 8 days in both groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of enteroendocrine system (EES)-related peptides, including GLP-1, in metabolic syndrome and obesity-related diseases, focusing on their effects on hepatocellular FFA metabolism and energy homeostasis.
results_summary: The study highlights that EES-related peptides, particularly GLP-1, modulate hepatocellular FFA metabolism, promote satiety, and improve energy homeostasis, potentially offering therapeutic benefits for obesity-related diseases like NAFLD and NASH. Enhanced bile-salt flow post-bariatric surgery stimulates EES, which may contribute to hepatic steatosis elimination.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on metabolic syndrome, obesity, and related conditions)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of SLC10A transporters (NTCP and ASBT) in bile salt transport, their regulation, and implications for drug interactions and viral infections.
results_summary: The study found that NTCP and ASBT are crucial for bile salt transport and enterohepatic circulation, with NTCP also transporting non-bile salt substrates. Both transporters are inhibited by various drugs, with ASBT being more permissive to inhibition. NTCP also serves as a receptor for HBV and HDV entry into hepatocytes.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on molecular and cellular mechanisms).
interactions: Inhibited by a number of drugs (specific drugs not listed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of dietary interventions, including salt restriction, in improving dietary behaviors and health outcomes in workplace settings.
results_summary: The study evaluated environmental dietary modifications, including salt restriction, alongside nutrition education, but specific results regarding salt's effects were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Full-time employees aged 18-64 at multinational manufacturing workplaces in Cork, purchasing at least one main meal daily.
study_duration: Measurements were taken at baseline, 3-4 months, 7-9 months, and 13-16 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the urinary recovery levels of PABA and its potassium salt (aminobenzoate potassium) when administered in different forms (tablet/capsule vs. added to food) to assess their suitability for evaluating 24-hour urine collection completeness.
results_summary: The study found similar urinary recovery levels for PABA tablets (98.8%), aminobenzoate potassium capsules (95.1%), and PABA/aminobenzoate potassium added to food (93.2%), with no significant differences, suggesting aminobenzoate potassium is a viable alternative to PABA for urine collection assessment.
population_specificity: 20 healthy participants
study_duration: 3 test days separated by two 24-hour wash-out periods

study_goal: The study aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of intracameral bevacizumab injection for improving trabeculectomy outcomes in glaucoma patients, not Salt.
results_summary: The study found that intracameral bevacizumab reduced the need for additional interventions post-trabeculectomy but did not address Salt.
population_specificity: Patients with medically uncontrolled open-angle glaucoma scheduled for primary trabeculectomy.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on bevacizumab, not Salt).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a sodium reduction program involving community health education and access to salt substitutes in lowering dietary sodium intake and controlling blood pressure in rural Chinese populations.
results_summary: The study implemented a large-scale intervention with salt substitutes and health education, showing good balance across groups at baseline, but final outcome data (e.g., sodium intake reduction) was not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Rural residents from five Northern Chinese provinces (120 villages across 60 townships).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved access to salt substitutes with partial subsidization).
study_duration: Intervention commenced May-June 2011, with outcome surveys scheduled for October-December 2012 (~17-18 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a comprehensive CVD risk reduction package, including salt reduction counseling, could reduce CVD events among high-risk patients in rural China.
results_summary: The study evaluated a combined intervention of lifestyle counseling (including salt reduction) and medication, showing potential for reducing CVD events, though specific salt-related outcomes were not isolated.
population_specificity: Adults aged 50-74 in rural Zhejiang, China, with a 10-year CVD risk ≥20% or diabetes.
effective_dosage: Not specified (lifestyle counseling included general salt reduction advice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate methods for assessing salt intake in hypertensive patients and provide guidance on salt reduction.
results_summary: The study found that different methods for assessing salt intake have varying reliability, with 24-h pooled urine or dietary surveys recommended for specialized facilities and spot urine samples for general medical facilities. A method using nighttime urine with an electronic salt sensor was noted as useful for home monitoring despite lower reliability.
population_specificity: Hypertensive patients
effective_dosage: Salt-reduction guidance targeting <6 g (Na: 100 mmol) per day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of immune mechanisms, particularly T-cell subsets, in hypertension and cardiovascular disease, with a focus on salt-sensitive models like the Dahl-salt sensitive rat.
results_summary: The study found that pro-inflammatory T-lymphocytes contribute to cardiovascular disease mechanisms, including hypertension, while regulatory T-cells (T(reg)) protect against blood pressure elevation. These immune mechanisms, demonstrated in murine models, may also occur in humans.
population_specificity: Dahl-salt sensitive rats and spontaneously hypertensive rats (experimental models); potential relevance to humans suggested.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of aliskiren, a renin inhibitor, in preventing renal disease progression in RAAS-activated hypertensive mice fed a high-salt diet.
results_summary: High-salt-loaded THM exhibited severe hypertension and renal injury, which was mitigated by antihypertensive treatments. Aliskiren showed stronger renoprotective effects than ramipril by suppressing both angiotensin I and II.
population_specificity: Tsukuba hypertensive mice (THM), double transgenic mice carrying human renin and angiotensinogen genes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between dietary salt consumption and blood pressure, as well as its broader effects on cardiovascular health and complications.
results_summary: The study found that stricter salt reduction significantly decreases blood pressure and may reduce the risk of cardiovascular diseases, particularly stroke, though effects vary by complication type. Excess salt was linked to increased risks of left ventricular hypertrophy, heart failure, and renal issues.
population_specificity: General population, with specific mention of high salt intake in Japan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the role of the bile salt export pump (BSEP) in bile acid clearance and the potential for drug-induced cholestasis and liver injury due to BSEP inhibition.
results_summary: The study highlights the complexity of bile acid transport, metabolism, and regulation, emphasizing the need to consider multiple factors, including transporter inhibition, enzyme activity, and nuclear hormone receptor function, when assessing drug-induced liver injury.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on hepatocytes and bile acid transport mechanisms)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the bidirectional interplay between aldosterone and parathyroid hormone (PTH) and their potential impact on cardiovascular, metabolic, and bone health, particularly in the context of excess dietary salt intake.
results_summary: The study found that excess dietary salt intake leads to relative aldosterone excess, which interacts with PTH to increase cardiovascular risk, metabolic disturbances, and bone diseases. Mineralocorticoid receptor blockade and adrenalectomy were shown to interrupt this adverse sequence.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of mechanisms, not a clinical trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of EPSs and biosurfactant produced by Paenibacillus macerans TKU029 in cosmetics, oil contamination removal, and as antimicrobial agents.
results_summary: The biosurfactant showed stability under high temperature (121 °C), a wide pH range (3-11), and in <5% salt solutions, along with significant antimicrobial activity. EPSs from TKU029 also demonstrated skin hydration effects (37.3-44.3% after 180 min).
population_specificity: Microbial strains (Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus aureus, Fusarium oxysporum, Aspergillus fumigatus) and human skin (hydration test).
effective_dosage: Not specified for human use; biosurfactant concentration tested at 2.76 g/L.
study_duration: 24-h reaction for emulsification index; 180 min for skin hydration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between excess salt intake and the risk of gastric cancer, including its cocarcinogenic effects with Helicobacter pylori infection.
results_summary: The study found a dose-dependent positive association between excess salt intake and gastric cancer risk, supported by epidemiological, clinical, and experimental evidence. A meta-analysis confirmed a strong adverse effect of high salt consumption on gastric cancer risk in the general population.
population_specificity: General population, with specific focus on dietary salt intake and Helicobacter pylori infection.
interactions: Synergistic effect with Helicobacter pylori infection mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers were examining pulmonary complications in chronic liver disease, including the role of salt restriction in managing hepatic hydrothorax.
results_summary: The study found that salt restriction is part of conservative management for hepatic hydrothorax, alongside diuretics, thoracentesis, and TIPS, with liver transplantation being the ultimate treatment.
population_specificity: Cirrhosis patients with hepatic hydrothorax (5%-10% of cirrhosis patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a novel HNO donor (CXL-1020) on myocardial function in experimental models and patients with heart failure.
results_summary: CXL-1020 significantly improved contractility, reduced filling pressures, and increased cardiac output in both animal models and human patients with heart failure, without significantly altering heart rate.
population_specificity: Adult mouse ventricular myocytes, anesthetized dogs with induced heart failure, conscious dogs with tachypacing-induced heart failure, and human patients with systolic heart failure.
effective_dosage: 50-500 μmol/L in myocytes; specific dosages for other models not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify genetic predictors of weight change during behavioral weight loss treatment, focusing on SNPs related to bile salt transfer and adipose tissue physiology.
results_summary: The study identified two novel genetic regions (ABCB11 and TNFRSF11A) associated with weight loss during behavioral intervention, with ABCB11 linked to higher weight and TNFRSF11A to lower weight per allele. These findings suggest potential biological mechanisms influencing weight loss outcomes.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese individuals with type 2 diabetes from the Look AHEAD trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of lower salt intake on the effectiveness of renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system blockage in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: Lower salt intake was associated with a greater effect of renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system blockage in CKD patients, suggesting improved hypertension management. The study also highlighted the benefits of lifestyle modifications, including weight loss, in reducing blood pressure in CKD patients.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic kidney disease (CKD), not on dialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of bile salt hydrolase-active L. reuteri NCIMB 30242 on gastrointestinal (GI) health status in hypercholesterolemic subjects using the Rome III questionnaire.
results_summary: Subjects receiving L. reuteri NCIMB 30242 reported significant improvements in general GI health status and diarrhea symptoms compared to placebo. A greater proportion of treated subjects showed improved GI health and diarrhea symptoms.
population_specificity: Otherwise healthy hypercholesterolemic subjects (n=127).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of plasma or cerebrospinal fluid hypernatremia in mediating sympathoexcitation and elevated arterial blood pressure in salt-sensitive hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that high salt intake increases plasma and cerebrospinal fluid sodium concentration, which activates the sympathetic nervous system, contributing to elevated blood pressure in salt-sensitive models. Both experimental and clinical studies support these findings.
population_specificity: Animals and humans (salt-sensitive hypertension models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of osmoregulation function in the pathophysiology of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) and its similarities to salt and water balance disorders in pregnancy and liver cirrhosis.
results_summary: The study highlights similarities in clinical and biochemical changes related to salt and water balance between OHSS, pregnancy, and liver cirrhosis, suggesting a potential role of osmoregulation dysfunction in OHSS. It supports further investigation into osmoregulation's role in managing OHSS.
population_specificity: Patients with severe ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the in vivo drug delivery and systemic exposure of salmeterol (as xinafoate salt) and fluticasone propionate delivered via two different inhalers (Rotahaler® and Diskus®).
results_summary: The study found that the Rotahaler showed higher systemic exposure for both drugs compared to the Diskus, but in vitro tests and pharmacodynamic endpoints showed no major differences. The inhalers were not bioequivalent in terms of systemic exposure.
population_specificity: Subjects with asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (n=60).
effective_dosage: Salmeterol 50 μg plus fluticasone propionate 250 μg (SFC 50/250), twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lifestyle interventions, including salt restriction, could reduce new vascular events in patients with noncardioembolic mild ischemic stroke.
results_summary: The study found that salt restriction, as part of a broader lifestyle intervention, significantly reduced salt intake (p < 0.001) and improved vascular risk factors, leading to fewer vascular events in the intervention group compared to controls.
population_specificity: Patients with acute noncardioembolic mild ischemic stroke (48 men, mean age 63.5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential misuse of cobalt (not salt) by athletes to stimulate erythropoiesis and its associated health risks.
results_summary: Cobalt ions effectively stimulated erythropoiesis but caused severe organ damage, including gastrointestinal, thyroid, cardiac, and sensory system issues. The study concluded that athletes should avoid cobalt intake due to these adverse effects.
population_specificity: Athletes seeking to enhance erythropoiesis (not specified beyond this).
effective_dosage: 25 to 300 mg daily (historical use as an anti-anaemic agent).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the test characteristics of the aldosterone-to-renin ratio (ARR) for diagnosing primary aldosteronism and assess the effect of combination antihypertensive treatment on ARR.
results_summary: The study found that ARR sensitivity for primary aldosteronism was low (22.2%) under random medication but specificity was high (98.7%). Standardized treatment increased ARR values, but reproducibility was poor, highlighting the need for alternative screening tests.
population_specificity: 178 patients with persistent hypertension despite using at least two antihypertensives.
